comments.commentBody: You have to ask, why don't "conservatives" want to "conserve" a natural ecosystem that is in some areas pristine and in some areas and in other areas in balance? Why don't "conservatives" want to preserve a human diet that is free of man-made interference in DNA?  "Conservative" corporations like Monsanto will sue you if you try that. Why don't "conservatives" want to preserve the commons, but instead force everything in the world into someone's ownership? As far as I can see, "conservatives" use ideology entirely to for one goal, power/wealth/control. They want to be free and unfettered in their desire to tell the rest of us what we can do, own, and think. They resent any infringement on their own power, both as individuals and as a group. No woman, for example, may have control over her own body as long as a conservative believes birth control is wrong. "Conservatives" want hegemony because the freedom of others takes away their power, not their freedom. Should the guy in the Romney video who needs medical marijuana to survive be allowed freedom to impinge upon Romney's belief that marijuana is wrong? Nosirree. As usual, the ideas follow the instincts. "Conservative" instincts are toward a hierarchical society with a few white men at the top, a highly unequal world where people who don't fit in die, and an entirely humanized and commodified nature that a few white men control. They construct ideas to justify these outcomes, but it is the outcomes that are important to them.

We really don't know what Gov. Huntsman intended to accomplish last summer.   It seems to me he accomplished almost nothing, certainly not Secretary of State next year, maybe ambassador to Vatican, a perfect fit for Mormon outreach in Holy See.

No doubt Mr. Huntsman has many virtues.  However, it is surely a measure of the Republicans' utter unwillingness to set forth coherent proposals for the benefit of the country that Huntsman, their most "reasonable" candidate, can think of no higher recommendation than that Romney might defeat the other party's candidate.  Of course we need not be surprised by the omission of substance: no one has yet detected any thought issuing from this band of bloviators which would or should be accepted by the public.
Guess who wants to be VP?

As an American concerned about my many friends who are out of work and the fact that my own family is just scraping by financially, I really would like to hear the Republican candidates explain how their "conservative ideas will create jobs, reduce our nation’s debt, stabilize energy prices and provide a brighter future."

Those conservative ideas have had 30 years -- since Reagan took office -- to bear fruit. The fruit is a decaying economy and Wall Street rotten to the core.

As long as "conservative ideas" embody things like cutting Medicaid, turning Medicare into a for-profit voucher system, raising the Social Security retirement age, abrogating collective bargaining rights, cutting pensions for public workers, etc., can we expect them to bear any less bitter fruit?

As for the "class warfare" comment, the Right has been waging class warfare for 30 years. It's only called "class warfare" when the 99% fight back.

I don't know. It's not that the ideas are crazy, most of them are truer than not. (ex. Israel didn't create Hamas per say, but did fund and support the establishment of supposedly "non-political" Islamic fundamentalist organizations to provide an alternative to the PLO which was Israel's big enemy in the 80's. Many of these Israeli supported and encouraged sheiks, muftis and hazans eventually found their way into Hamas)

The real problem with Paul's ideas is that so many of them fly in the face of received mainstream wisdom. This in turn is why, the more that stick-up-their butt pols like Huntsman attack Paul, the more popular he becomes, especially among the young. After all it wasn't Romney who sucked the air out of the Huntsman room at the Hotel New Hampshire, it was Paul.

Ah! Jon, we barely knew ye.

Found scribed in the granite of a headstone:
'chastising President Obama for engaging in “class warfare.”'

There's your problem, you don't sound any different than the others.

So Huntsman is hoping his big 5 percent will unite the party or is he really trying to set himself up for 2016? Even a republican like Huntsman cannot be so naive to believe that the poor and middle class have gotten anything in a long time to gain the upper hand. The last time I checked, Wall street and the bankers were winning, the other 99 percent were protesting in the streets, and they were mad as hell about it. Yes, it looks like Huntsman is saying all the right things finally to position  a bid for 2016. I think he finally gets it that common sense and putting the country before party doesn't score any points with this crowd.

Someone should remind Mr. Huntsman that it is his fellow Republicans who are engaging in class warfare with ads that point out the obvious: that years of policies that favor corporations and the rich have decimated the middle class. The bank bailout was a transfer of hundreds of billions of dollars from middle class taxpayers to wealthy bankers and yet when people criticize this redistribution of wealth to the rich we are somehow un-American and practicing class warfare. Americans are not going to just talk about it in "quiet rooms" as the hatchet man, Mitt Romney suggests, but are going to scream it from the rooftops every day until the election. Note to Obma: this is the message that terrifies the Republicans. They know they are vulnerable on this, they know this is what will cost them the election if the dems follow up on it.

One has to wonder what Jon Huntsman actually believes. In Utah, he was an excellent moderate governor....but then he resigned to work in the Obama administration and left us with a frighteningly reactionary replacement. He ran for President as someone who questioned the crazy tea party orthodoxy and then turns around and tells us to vote for someone who is running on an extreme right wing  anti-science, anti-civil rights, anti-government platform. Does he believe anything? No wonder people are disgusted with politicians.

To my way of thinking, Mr. Huntsman is putting the good of his party ahead of the good of his country.  Uniting the Republican Party is not good if it is accomplished at the cost of giving undue influence to extremists -- which, at the moment, would be the only way to get that unity.

Oh, I get it now -- Bain Capital paid a visit to Huntsman headquarters, bought it outright, and has now shut it down.... in typical Romney fashion!

Clever boys, those Republicants.

In bowing out of the campaign, Huntsman accused the President of engaging in class warfare. I think it is important to respond each time any member of the GOP alleges that Democrats are engaging in class warfare.  My own response is that it is the GOP that has engaged in class warfare and that  for decades it has successfully amplified all the advantages that the wealthy enjoy over middle class, working class, and poor families.  The Democrats are not engaging in class warfare; they are calling attention to the class warfare being waged by Republicans.

Why did he endorse Romney so soon? It takes all of the drama out of the Presidential race. What a waste of my time. I'm voting for Obama anyway.

Obama '12

Jon Huntsman is in heart, a Democrat, but, due to the ramifications of switching political parties, and since we are a two-party system, he is doomed to oblivion because of his long ago chosen political affiliation.
Given that Huntsman is the most intelligent of the bunch it's painful to see him trot out the "class warfare" nonsense.  He knows it isn't true but I suppose he's angling for the VP spot.

I gather he was a good ambassador to China.

I am sorry to see that being a Republican to him is more important than maintaining his reputation for integrity. But maybe he's trying to bank some good will for his chance four years from now.

The "class warfare" line is dumb and unworthy of him. It's also incredibly tone deaf. "Class warfare" ceased to be a useful trope when it was replaced by "income disparity" which resonates with people all across the political spectrum. "Class warfare" is the mantra of the haves afraid someone will take it away from them.

Mr. Huntsman, is it class warfare to point out facts that show American families who have 2 parents working full time have lost ground since the advent of the Republican trickle down economic theory? You appeared to be an honest conservative American, but you like John McCain, have turned out to be a wealthy American who will do anything to protect the uber wealthy from paying taxes and joining the 99% of Americans who are shouldering the burden and the pain of this economy you are responsible for. Hopefully, you will have enough moral resolve to not join the rightwing enemies of the American people and their government, but your statements give me little hope. I will stop here so you can get your proper thoghts and talking points as dictated to you by your corporate handlers.
Sincerely yours,
An American who does not worship money and the monied and who is willing to sacrifice for this country I love!!

He's just following the Republican play-book.  Get ready to see that meme repeated over and over until election day.  The Repugs are terrified by a backlash from the OWS movement (as they should be).  They have sold their soul and the soul of the nation to Wall Street and they are terrified that the American people -- even their party faithful -- have figured it out.  They are going to do their best to brainwash people that voting against their own financial interests is in their best interests.  They've been able to convince the rubes for the past 30 years that trickle down economics works, and they are hoping they can keep us from figuring out that that there is no Wizard behind the curtain, but a big fat fraudster.   It is up to the rest of us to educate our family, friends, and neighbors about the truth.  That the free-market isn't free at all, but tilted in favor of the 1%, and we're paying to support their lavish lifestyles.   Truth will set us all free.

I have watched all of the Republican debates on TV, and always felt that Huntsman was the most reasonable, erudite, and unappreciated.

Not after today. That silly and untrue comment about President Obama and "class warfare" now puts him in the same category as Rick Perry, Herman Cain, Michele Bachmann, and the absolutely ridiculous Newt Gingrich. Too bad! I guess he drank the Kool-Aid and decided to just sound like all the rest instead of being the independent, critical thinker I believed him to be.

In a world in which we have seen Republican candidates and Tea Party supporters misuse words like "socialist," "fascist," "radical," etc, Huntsman was a breath of fresh air. No more, I'm afraid.

The GOP needs to remove the evangelical right from their party and go back to the pre Ronald Reagan GOP platform. Religion does not have a place in our government and politicians need not function as if religion is the basis for government function for it is not, never was, never will be.

The GOP has become the ultimate party of exclusion, bigotry, deception, and irresponsibility. They hold a contempt for the average American.

There is no question that George "W" was the most fiscally irresponsible president that our country ever experienced. We are paying dearly for he and his parties lack of oversight, responsibility, and policies created from poor judgment and special interest.

There is no question that the GOP ended depression era bank regulations that led banks down a self serving merry path creating the current economic mess of the world and our country.

The GOP is unwilling to rise above the special interest groups of Grover Norquist, the Koch brothers, religious family value hypocrites and so many more. The GOP is a threatening group promoting irresponsible value not to tax payers but to corporations and special interest.

The GOP has become to me, the ultimate club of thieves, liars, bigots, who operate through the concept of confirmation bias, delusions, narcissism, and out right self service.

GOP, clean up your act, stand up and act like real men and women, be responsible, and stop telling us lies.
Come back to Utah Mr Huntsman.  The state was a better place when you were here to reign in the crazies.

Odd Ball. What's his schtick, really? I'm the "good Republican?" The rest of them are a shot put away from being institutionalized, so what! These people don't have a chance in any contest involving reality, the Evangelicals have already cornered the market on that.
Trashing an opponent one day to filth, embracing him the next is as American as apple pie. I don't see any disconnect here.

What a loser.He does a hatchet job on Romney while campaigning then falls to his knees and ask forgiveness and endorsed him.Typical Republican Politician.No backbone and will change course if it will benefit them down the road.He probably thinks with his endorsement he may get a job if Mr. i'm everything to everybody wins the Presidency.

@ J-

"Anytime we are taxed for anything we are "losing our liberty" to spend that money as we wish. We may agrre with it or not, we may feel there is value or not, we may think the money is being spent wisely or not, but nevertheless we lose freedom."

Sorry, but I ain't buyin' it.

Freedom is not money.

Let's say that a woman chose to live her entire adult life as a nun, she would be free and have little or no money. She could vote, she could go to church, she could go to a Tea Party or OWS meeting, she could write articles about anything she wanted.

And if you'd like to eliminate the federal income tax and go back to financing the federal government with tariffs - I have no problem with that. But good luck. As crazy as it sounds, the rich people won't let that happen. Charities, think tanks, lobbyists all enjoy their existence thanks to the special breaks they get in the tax code.

This may be of interest:
http://www.c-span.org/Events/In-Depth-with-Author-and-Journalist-Chris-H...
Mr. Hedges is a guy who has plenty of criticism for both the left and the right and is very well-read and articulate. Enjoy.
